citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The nonhuman primate environmental enhancement plan is incomplete and was not developed with the direction of the
attending veterinarian. The facility individually houses one five week old ring-tailed lemur. The nonhuman primate
environmental enhancement plan addresses environmental enrichment but does not address the social needs or the
special considerations related to an individually housed nonhuman primate. The plan also fails to address the special
considerations associated with an infant nonhuman primate. Failure to establish and maintain an adequate plan for the
environmental enhancement of nonhuman primates can result in psychological distress and negatively impact the well-
being of the animals. Facilities must develop, document and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement
adequate to promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates. The plan must be in accordance with the
currently accepted professional standards and as directed by the attending veterinarian.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by June 30, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.81 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The nonhuman primate environmental enhancement plan is incomplete and was not developed with the direction of the 
attending veterinarian. The facility individually houses one five week old ring-tailed lemur. The nonhuman primate 
environmental enhancement plan addresses environmental enrichment but does not address the social needs or the 
special considerations related to an individually housed nonhuman primate. The plan also fails to address the special 
considerations associated with an infant nonhuman primate. Failure to establish and maintain an adequate plan for the 
environmental enhancement of nonhuman primates can result in psychological distress and negatively impact the well-
being of the animals. Facilities must develop, document and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement 
adequate to promote the psychological well-being of nonhuman primates. The plan must be in accordance with the 
currently accepted professional standards and as directed by the attending veterinarian. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by June 30, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
